item.name: Subject Code - The Subject Codes is IPTC 's original subject taxonomy, with a focus on text. It consists of about 1400 terms organized into 3 levels.
arts, culture and entertainment - Matters pertaining to the advancement and refinement of the human mind, of interests, skills, tastes and emotions
archaeology - Probing the past through ruins and artefacts
architecture - Designing of buildings, monuments and the spaces around them
bullfighting - Classical contest pitting man against the bull
festive event (including carnival) - Parades, parties, celebrations and the like not necessarily tied to a fixed occasion or date
cinema - Cinema as art and entertainment
film festival - National and international motion pictures festivals, selections, festival juries, nominations, awards etc.
dance - The expression of emotion or message through movement
fashion - The design of clothing and accessories
jewelry - Accessories to clothing
language - The means by which people communicate with each other
library and museum - Edifices used to house collections of books, music, art, or objects from the past and present for public use and display
literature - The use of pamphlets, books or other printed matter to convey ideas, stories or other messages for the public
fiction - Structured stories that are usually not based on fact but are the creation of the authors imagination
poetry - The art, structure, forms of poetic expression
music - Expressing emotion or message through instruments or voice using different sounds, tones, harmonies and the like
classical music - Music that follows classic structures of rhythm and harmony
folk music - Music that developed from folk cultures, often based on story-telling
jazz music - A music of diverse harmonics, often improvised
popular music - The latest fad in music, generally aimed at the younger generation
country music - Similar to folk but is unique to the United States and is less about story telling than about loves sought and lost
rock and roll music - Popular dance music developed in the 1950s
hip-hop - A contemporary urban music originating in the 1970s.
painting - Using the mediums of oils, watercolour, pastel, pencils, chalk, crayon etc on various grounds to express emotion or message
photography - Mechanical means of creating images of objects by use of light and light sensitive materials with chemicals or by digitals means
radio - Radio as art and entertainment
sculpture - Representation of forms in clays, stone, woods, metals or other materials
plastic art - Forms of hand created art including installations
television - Television as art and entertainment
soap opera - Episodic TV drama or saga, normally aired during daytime
theatre - Telling of a story or idea through dialogue, music and physical expression in a space or building designed for it
music theatre - Opera, operetta, music revues etc
monument and heritage site - Areas containing commemorative objects for historical people or events
institution-DEPRECATED - NA
customs and tradition - A particular way of behaving, or observances that have developed over time by a group of people
arts (general) - The collective expression of message or emotion through music, literature, painting, theatre or other means
entertainment (general) - The collective use of television, radio, theatre, music and the like for the amusement of people
entertainment award - Awards for achievement in the entertainment industry, such as the Oscars for film, the Booker Prize for Literature, the Grammys for music, or induction into halls of fame.
culture (general) - The ideas, customs, arts, skills of a particular group
cultural development - The history of the development of art and culture such as the rise of cave paintings, pre-Colombian art, Chinese paper-making, anything non-political
nightclub - A commercial establishment providing music, or other entertainment along with food and drink to selected clientele
cartoon - Still images such as editorial cartoons and comic strips
animation - Animation, including full-length and short cinema, artists and merchandising of goods featuring animation characters.
mass media - Television, radio, magazines, newspapers etc
periodicals - Written material that is usually published weekly, bi-weekly, monthly or annually for a long time
news media - Television, wire services, radio that collect facts about incidents, developing and presenting them to audiences as a whole story
newspapers - Daily or weekly publications that present the day to day history of the world, as well as features, comics etc
reviews - A critical look at someone else's work, whether film, theatre or writing
internet - Internet as art and entertainment
history - Issues connected with the past; discoveries, repair, conservation or display of artifacts; anniversaries of historic events

crime, law and justice - Establishment and/or statement of the rules of behaviour in society, the enforcement of these rules, breaches of the rules and the punishment of offenders. Organizations and bodies involved in these activities.
crime - Violation of established laws by individuals, companies or organizations
homicide - Killing of one person by another
computer crime - Theft or destructive behaviour using a computer
theft - Unlawful taking
drug trafficking - Dealing in illicit often harmful substances
sexual assault - Sexual battery of one sex against another
assault (general) - Battery, slugfests, brawls and threatening behaviour
kidnapping - To seize and detain or carry away a person against that person's will by unlawful threat, force or fraud
arson - Intentional setting of fires with criminal intent
gang activity - Criminal activities by groups of individuals, usually in urban areas, who are allied by common territories, languages, ethnic backgrounds but generally are loosely organized.
terrorism - Violence against people to create fear in order to achieve political or ideological objectives
judiciary (system of justice) - The system set up to deal with crime and those who do them
lawyer - Anyone legally able to represent another person or entity in a legal matter, such as a lawyer, solicitor, barrister, procurator, notary.
judge - Members of the bench that sit in judgement
court administration - Court clerks, bailiffs, stenographers etc.
police - Agents of the legal system set up enforce the laws
law enforcement - Agencies involved in attempts to prevent disobedience to established laws, or to bring to justice those that disobey those laws
investigation - Process of inquiry of a possible crime up to the point of arrest
arrest - Detention of a suspect of a crime
punishment - The retribution handed out to those who break the laws
fine - Monetary punishment
execution - The carrying out of executions by a government or state, not by extralegal groups/organisations
prison - Also know as jails, lockups, calaboose, etc. for keeping law breakers from society
laws - The codification of rules of behaviour
criminal - The criminal code system
civil - The civil code system
justice and rights - The equitable administration of laws and regulations
civil rights - Rights of individuals under civil law
trials - The process by which guilt or innocence, or right or wrong is determined and adjudged
litigation - Taking disputed issues to court for settlement by judge and/or jury
arbitration - Resolution of disputed issues by a neutral panel
court preliminary - Pre-trial events including pleas, bail, motions, discovery, depositions.
prosecution - Stories regarding activities and investigations by public prosecutors.
defendant - The person on trial
witness - A person who testifies
organized crime - Crimes committed by gangs or criminal groups.
international law - The system of laws embraced by all nations, such as the Geneva Convention, the International Law of the Seas, etc.
international court or tribunal - The activities of international tribunals such as European court for human rights, Hague tribunal, International Court of Justice etc
extradition - Legal transfer of criminals or suspects between countries
corporate crime - Misdeeds of corporations and corporate officers
fraud - Intentional deception that causes others to give up rights or property
embezzlement - The intentional theft of money left in one's care
restraint of trade - Interference in free competition in business and trade
breach of contract - Rupture of legal agreements between companies, and with customers
anti-trust crime - Violations of laws against monopolies
corruption - General business misbehaviour
bribery - Payments or benefits to influence the outcome of a legal case
war crime - Crimes committed during a war or armed conflict, usually against civilians or POW's, including the prosecution of such crimes
inquest - Formal investigation of sudden or unexpected death and the hearing to decide cause of death.
inquiry - Formal hearing involving a disaster, political event etc. Eg rail crash, drug prescription scandal.
tribunal - Formal hearing usually involving employment issues, property etc.
disaster and accident - Man made and natural events resulting in loss of life or injury to living creatures and/or damage to inanimate objects or property.
drought - A severe lack of water over a period of time
earthquake - The shifting of the tectonic plates of the Earth, creating in some cases damage to structures
famine - Severe lack of food for a large population
fire - Ignition and consumption of materials through a combination of high heat and oxygen
flood - Surfeit of water, caused by heavy rains or melting snow, usually in places where it's not wanted
industrial accident - A mishap in a factory, a shop or an office, potentially harmful to humans
structural failures - When a building, bridge or other structures collapse because of unexpected forces or poor design
meteorological disaster - A weather-related disaster
windstorms - A storm of high velocity but non-hurricane force movements of air with little or no rain or hail. Often highly destructive
nuclear accident - A mishap involving radioactive materials
pollution - Emissions of unwanted materials in areas where it can be harmful
transport accident - An accident involving one or more vehicles
road accident - Accidents on roads.
railway accident - Accidents involving trains.
air and space accident - Accidents involving craft in air or space.
maritime accident - Accidents involving marine vessels.
volcanic eruption - A rupture in the skin of the Earth allowing molten material to escape to the surface
relief and aid organisation - Organizations set up to provide help to those in need because of lack of food, water or shelter
accident (general) - Any unplanned event that causes unwanted consequences
emergency incident - A sudden, unexpected event that requires immediate action
explosion - Sudden eruptions, usually of chemical substances
disaster (general) - Serious or sudden misfortune
natural disasters - Destructive incidents caused by the very nature of nature -- hurricanes, earthquakes, floods etc
avalanche/landslide - Sudden dislodging of massive amounts of snow or soil.
emergency planning - Planning for actions to deal with sudden, unplanned events
rescue - An operation to save people, animals or property from harm or danger.
economy, business and finance - All matters concerning the planning, production and exchange of wealth.
agriculture - The process of producing natural materials for consumption
arable farming - Production of food in the ground
fishing industry - Raising or gathering of fish
forestry and timber - Production and collection and preparation of wood products for future use
livestock farming - Raising of animals for food
viniculture - Production of wines from the vines to the finish products
aquaculture - Growing plants or animals in water for human consumption
chemicals - Natural or manmade materials used to produce other materials
biotechnology - The business of using engineering technology to study and solved problems of living organisms
fertiliser - Natural or manmade materials used to encourage the growth of plants
health and beauty product - Compilation of chemicals and other substances for use in enhancing ones looks or smell
inorganic chemical - The branch of chemistry dealing with minerals and metals
organic chemical - The branch of chemistry dealing with human, animal or carbon-based substances
pharmaceutical - The production of medicines from various chemicals and natural substances
synthetic and plastic - Chemicals used to produce plastics and other artificial substances to be used in manufacturing
computing and information technology - Anything to do with the computing and/or transmission of information from one point to another.
hardware - The physical devices used to provide computer services, such as monitors, hard drives, keyboards etc. but can also be used for equipment such as routers, servers and other network devices.
networking - The interconnectivity between hardware that provides the medium for the transmission of data.
satellite technology - Hardware and software that enables groundbased devices to send signals to each other via an orbiting satellite.
semiconductors and active components - The basic components that together create working electronic devices such as computers
software - Programming sets that, when installed on hardware, perform specified functions.
telecommunication equipment - Devices such as telephone sets, voice/data switches, modems etc that facilitate point-to-point voice/data transmissions
telecommunication service - Services provided by commercial companies that facilitate connections between telephones, pagers, computers
security - To encompass technical developments in hardware and software, basic research and related areas such as cyber security
wireless technology - Transmission of information through means other than point-to-point wired hookups
construction and property - All items pertaining to the construction and sale of property
heavy construction - Large scale construction projects, construction of roads, dams, office/factory buildings, offshore and onshore structures, large sport stadiums
house building - Construction of residences, for private use
real estate - The buying and selling of properties of all types
farms - Agricultural areas for the production of foodstuffs, including dairy products, fruits and livestock, such as cattle and fish
land price - The price of land in specific zoned areas such as commercial, residential arable as provided by a responsible body
renovation - Restoring properties/structures to a former better state by cleaning, repairing or rebuilding.
design and engineering - Design and planning by Engineers, Architects etc. of roads, offices, factories, dams , offshore structures,
energy and resource - Production of electrical power, and the water, air, sunlight, and fuels used to produce them
alternative energy - Alternative energy business
coal - Production and mining of anthracite and bituminous products for use in power production
oil and gas - downstream activities - All matters concerning oil and gas, typically refining and distribution activities
oil and gas - upstream activities - All matters concerning oil and gas, typically supply chain activities from the reservoir to the refinery gate
nuclear power - Use of radioactive materials for power production
electricity production and distribution - Primarily concerning the power line distribution system, but also the sale of electrical power at wholesale and retail levels
waste management and pollution control - The business of waste management and pollution control
water supply - The business of providing water for human use
natural resources (general) - The general use of natural resources for business purposes, not focused on specific resources such as coal, oil, gas or water
energy (general) - Energy industry, not focused on any specific sector
natural gas - A natural resource, mainly methane in an flammable gaseous state, from the ground
petrol - Distilled petroleum product used for automotive fuel, with or without additives
diesel fuel - A distilled petroleum product heavier than gasoline used not only for trucks, marine engines, but in certain forms for home heating
kerosene/paraffin - A light petroleum distillate used for cooking fuel, aircraft jet engines, lamps, heating and cleaning
financial and business service - Services that transmit, safeguard, keep track of money or provide backup to commercial enterprises
accountancy and auditing - Services provide balance sheet, budgets reconciliation and examine accuracy of financial statements
banking - Services for storing, transmitting, receiving and delivery of cash moneys
consultancy service - Providers of expert knowledge in a wide range of fields usually on a temporary, contract basis
employment agency - A service helping people find jobs, and companies to find workers
healthcare provider - Providers of medical services at all levels, including doctors, hospitals etc
insurance - A risk taking venture that allows individuals to pay small amounts periodically to guard financially against unexpected events
legal service - Lawyers and others who help companies and individuals deal with state, federal and local laws
market research - A service that tries to determine what people want to buy
stock broking - The buying and selling of company shares on behalf of individuals or other entities
personal investing - Personal finance and investment
market trend - Statistically significant consumer behaviour.
shipping service - Companies that prepare and transport packages and documents for individuals or companies by any means, including postal services.
personal service - Consumer service that is intangible e.g. beauty care as in hairdressing
janitorial service - Companies that provide cleaning and similar services for homes and businesses.
funeral parlour and crematorium - Companies that provide services for disposal of the dead
rental service - Companies which provide rentals, including motor vehicles, tuxedos, tools, heavy equipment, and other supplies
wedding service - Services and products related to the wedding industry
personal finance - An individual's income and expenses
personal income - Money that a person earns and is his/hers to keep or spend
auction service - Sales by bidding
printing/promotional service - Production of printed matter such as flyers, ads, signs etc
investment service - Financial advisers, as opposed to stock dealers or consultants
consumer goods - Items produced for and sold to individuals
clothing - Items of apparel to wear
department store - Stores largely devoted to the sale of clothing to individuals
food - Fruits, vegetables, breads, meats for human consumption
mail order - Items sold through and delivered by mail
retail - The last stage in the sales chain
speciality store - Retail outlets that specialize in categories such as shoes, coats, power tools, etc
wholesale - The first link in the sales chain after production
beverage - Liquid consumables, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic
electronic commerce - Buying and selling items through the Internet
luxury good - Leather bags, jewellery, haute couture, accessories etc
non-durable good - Lighters, pens and stationery, tableware, watches, glasses etc
toy - Children's plaything
macro economics - Broad scale economics and the world or national level
central bank - A country's major bank that sets interest rates, and provides transfer of funds between commercial banks
consumer issue - Those issues, such as prices, inflation/deflation, quality of goods, at the retail sales level
debt market - Market for trading debt instruments such as bonds, CDs, bankers acceptances, T bills, notes, IOUs etc
economic indicator - Certain indexes, such as company inventories, the movement of prices that show whether the economy is improving or declining
emerging market - Those markets that are struggling to enter the world economies and those requiring financial help from international lenders
foreign exchange market - The trading of shekels, dinars, euros dollars etc around the world through regulated markets
government aid - Supply of financial and other help by one government, usually to another
government debt - The amount a government owes on bonds, services and for goods and services for which it has no ready cash
interest rate - The amount of money one must pay to borrow money
international economic institution - Entities such as UNIDO, World Bank, World Trade Organization, the Import-Expert Bank etc that deals at a world level
international (foreign) trade - Trade of goods and services between nations
loan market - The market where money is available to borrow, at certain rates of interest
economic organization - Business, industrial and trade associations, societies and other private-sector groups.
consumer confidence - Reports on consumer confidence in the economy.
trade dispute - International dispute over trade barriers, cartels, dumping etc.
inflation and deflation - An increase in the amount of money in circulation and thereby a rise in prices; deflation, tighter monetary policy causing lower prices
prices - The monetary value of goods, services or stocks and bonds
currency values - The value of one currency as measured against another
budgets and budgeting - A method of balancing revenues against expenses
credit and debt - Credit

parents.item: the amount of money available to you

item.name: loans - An agreement by one individual or institution to temporarily disperse money to another, with an agreed rate and time for its return
mortgages - The loan of money for the purpose of purchasing a property, whether land or building. Or, for homeowners to repair or maintain properties, often based on owner equity in a property
financial markets - Institutions set up to trade the shares or other financial paper of companies or other organizations, can also include currency trading
commodity markets - The bartering or trading of goods such as cotton, oil, coal, metals, etc
investments - Speculative purchases of corporate instruments, of commodities, currencies, or parts thereof
stocks - Corporate paper that gives an individual an ownership right to a part of a company's earnings
bonds - Corporate or governmental paper representing the loan of money at a fixed rate and for a fixed time to that company or government
mutual funds - Pools of shares or bonds for sale often grouped by investment intention, such as growth, income or security

derivative securities - Financial instruments such as futures, swaps and options, used for risk management, whose characteristics and value depend upon the characteristics and value of an underlying instrument, such as a commodity, bond, equity or currenc
imports - What is bought abroad and brought into a country for resale
exports - What is produced or manufactured in your country and sent and sold elsewhere
trade agreements - Government level agreements between countries for the sale and purchase of goods and services
trade policy - Governmental decisions on tariffs, shipping, embargoes, and the types or kinds of goods and services to be imported and exported
business enterprises - Organizations set up usually for profit-making purposes by creating and selling a product or service
tariff - Fees placed on goods imported or exported, often punitive
trade balance - The difference between the financial value of imports and exports
market and exchange - Organized entities for buying and selling stocks, currencies, commodities and other goods
energy - Stories related to energy trading and markets
metal - Markets for trading base metals such as copper, aluminium, steel, zinc etc
securities - Markets for trading types of company paper such as stocks and bonds
soft commodity - Trading in commodities such as cotton, sugar, sorghum, soybeans etc.
media - The various means of disseminating news and information to the public
advertising - Methods of promoting goods and service to consumers through video, graphics, print text etc
book - The business of producing and selling bound media, whether fiction or non-fiction
cinema industry - The business of cinema
news agency - Commercial agencies for production and distribution of newsworthy events through print, broadcast, video or electronic media
newspaper and magazine - The business of producing bound and unbound printed paper products for periodic distribution of news items
online - The business of distributing news and information through computer networks for public consumption
public relation - The job of promoting products and services through advertising campaigns and/or through person-to-person contact or through news releases
radio industry - Business of radio
satellite and cable service - The business of transmitting of news, entertainment and information via satellite or cable television services
television industry - Business of television
music industry - Recording, production, marketing of music
manufacturing and engineering - Manufacturers of electrical, electronic and mechanical equipment but does not cover civil engineering.
aerospace - Companies that assemble or manufacture components for airplanes and space ships.
automotive equipment - Companies that produce components for automobiles
defence equipment - Manufacturers of guns, tanks, cannons, ships etc for the military and non-military protection services
electrical appliance - Makers of large and small electrical goods for use in homes or business
heavy engineering - Manufacturers of cranes, bulldozers and the like for use in major construction projects
industrial component - Manufacturers of mechanical, electrical, electronic items needed in the manufacture of other items
instrument engineering - Manufacturers of instruments for calibration, measurement of things like speed, pressure, distance
shipbuilding - Manufacturers of ships, submarines, barges.
machine manufacturing - Manufacturers of turbines, engines, fans , pumps , motors and components for powered equipment.
metal and mineral - Production and refining of ores into metals
building material - Manufacture of materials like wallboard, lumber wiring for the building industry
gold and precious material - Mining, refining and sales of gold and other precious metals
iron and steel - Mining, refining and sales of iron-based metals
non ferrous metal - Mining, refining and sales of copper, zinc, aluminium, and other metals not based on iron
mining - The industry of digging for metals, raw materials such as coal, or precious gems such as diamonds
process industry - The business of turning raw materials into useable products
distiller and brewer - Manufacture of alcoholic beverages
food - The business of processing, distributing and selling for basic human consumption
furnishings and furniture - Manufacture of furniture, wallpaper, paints and fabrics for interior decoration
paper and packaging product - Production of paper material for writing, wrapping, printing, or packaging
rubber product - Production of rubber based materials for gloves, protective coatings, hoses and the like
soft drinks - Production of non-alcoholic drinks
textile and clothing - Production of fabrics for furnishings and fixtures, and for clothing of various types
tobacco - Growing, producing and sale of tobacco products
tourism and leisure - Tourism and leisure industries
casino and gambling - The business of providing outlets for various games of chance using cards, dice, spinning wheels to betting on animal races
hotel and accommodation - The business of providing food and shelter to travellers
recreational and sporting goods - Manufacture of goods for leisure activities
restaurant and catering - The business of providing prepared foods for customers in groups large and small
tour operator - Operators of trips either locally, as around town, or to other countries
transport - The means of getting from one place to the other without walking
air transport - Airplane and airport operations
railway - The business of transporting people or cargo by rail
road transport - The business of transport goods by trucks and highways
waterway and maritime transport - Commercial movement of people or goods via boats, ships and water
company information - Information about individual companies or business entities
accounting and audit - Changes in choice of auditing firm. Reports on impact of changes in GAAP.
annual and special corporate meeting - Announcements of upcoming meetings. Reports on meetings.
annual report - Availability or contents of annual company reports.
antitrust issue - Antitrust activities, monopoly regulation, etc.
merger, acquisition and takeover - News on mergers, takeovers or acquisitions.
analysts' comment - Stock analyst comments, analysis and recommendations.
bankruptcy - Actual bankruptcy filings.
board of directors (appointment and change) - Appointments to or changes in the board of directors for a company.
buyback - Stock buyback programs. This should be kept distinct from Stock Activity (see below).
C.E.O. interview - Interviews with Chief Executive Officers.
corporate officer - Appointments or changes in corporate officers.
corporate profile - Descriptive profiles of companies.
contract - Commercial contracts.
defence contract - The award of government contracts for defence related activity.
dividend announcement - Announcements regarding the disbursement of dividends.
earnings forecast - Analyst prediction of company earnings.
financially distressed company - Aa company is financially distressed - not yet having filed for bankruptcy.
earnings - Any increase of earnings results.
financing and stock offering - New offerings of equity including initial public offerings.
government contract - The award of government contracts not related to defence activity
global expansion - Planned or actual openings of offices in countries for the first time.
insider trading - The purchase or sales of stock by corporate officers or board members.
joint venture - Joint ventures between companies. (Not marketing related - see Marketing.)
leveraged buyout - Leveraged buyouts.
layoffs and downsizing - Planned or actual reductions in the labour force.
licensing agreement - Licensing agreements between companies.
litigation and regulation - Corporate law including litigation and regulations.
management change - Major appointments or changes in management below the level of corporate officer.
marketing - Includes news regarding joint marketing agreements between companies, adoption of new product marketing strategies, etc.
new product - Announcements of new products.
patent, copyright and trademark - News related to patents, copyright and trademarks.
plant closing - Announcements of planned or actual plant closings.
plant opening - Announcements of planned or actual plant openings.
privatisation - Privatisation (privatisation) of state run companies.
proxy filing - Filings with regulatory agencies of proxy statements for upcoming shareholder votes.
rating - Corporate and sovereign debt and credit ratings (e.g. SandP or Moody's)
research and development - Research and expenditure on new product development.
quarterly or semiannual financial statement - Availability or contents of quarterly or semi-annual corporate reports.
restructuring and recapitalisation - Sale of company units, splits of existing companies into units under a holding company, etc.
spin-off - Creation of new companies being spun off from existing companies.
stock activity - Announcements of major stock events
industrial production - Manufacture of durable and non-durable goods
productivity - The cost of labour to produce an item of value, often measured as output per hour per person
inventories - Goods not sold and held by the producer, wholesaler or retailer
sales - Either the exchange of goods for money, or the practice of discounting prices to increase the amount of goods sold, or to get rid of outdated merchandise
corporations - Business enterprises formally licensed with boards of directors and hierarchical structures of governance
shareholders - Anyone holding a piece of paper issued by a company which changes in value and entitles them to dividends depending on the performance of the company
corporate performance - How well a company performs, measured by its net earnings, its dividends its earnings per share and price/earnings ratio
losses - When expenses exceed revenue
credit ratings - Formal statements by certain rating agencies such as Standard and Poor's on the investment risk of a company, a country or enterprise

stock splits - Issuing multiple shares for one share of stock. Usually occurs when the price of a stock has increased so much that its purchase price is not attractive. A reverse split is when one share is issued for multiple shares, to raise the per shar
stock options - An agreement to either buy or sell a stock when it meets a certain price
recalls (products) - A decision by a company to take back or repair a defective product
globalization - Doing business around the world
consumers - Buyers of goods and services
purchase - Items that companies buy, such as raw materials, office supplies etc.
new service - New services added by a company, such as new flight routes, etc.
economy (general) - Content of a general nature about trade and the economy
economic policy - Government directed policy on production, taxes, tariffs and things that affect the direction and health of the economy
business (general) - Content of a general nature about business
institution - Either an established law, practice or system or an organization having a social, religious, educational or similar purpose such as hospital, school, prison
finance (general) - Content of a general nature about finance
money and monetary policy - Government bank directed policy on the amount of money in circulation and the rate at which it can be loaned
education - All aspects of furthering knowledge of human individuals from birth to death.
adult education - Education provided for older students outside the usual age groups of 5-25
further education - Any form of education beyond basic education of several levels
parent organisation - Groups of parents set up to support schools
preschool - Education for children under the national compulsory education age
school - A building or institution in which education of various sorts is provided
elementary schools - Schools usually of a level from kindergarten through 11 or 12 years of age
middle schools - Transitional school between elementary and high school, 12 through 13 years of age
high schools - Pre-college/ university level education, 14 to 17 or 18 years of age, called freshman, sophomore, junior and senior
teachers union - Organization of teachers for collective bargaining and other purposes
university - Institutions of higher learning capable of providing doctorate degrees
upbringing - Lessons learned from parents and others as one grows up

entrance examination - Exams for entering colleges, universities, junior and senior high schools, and all other higher and lower education institutes, including cram schools, which help students prepare for exams for entry to prestigious schools.
teaching and learning - Either end of the education equation
students - People of any age in a structured environment, not necessarily a classroom, in order to learn something
teachers - People with knowledge who can impart that knowledge to others
curriculum - The courses offered by a learning institution and the regulation of those courses
test/examination - A measurement of student accomplishment
religious education - Instruction by any faith, in that faith or about other faiths, usually, but not always, conducted in schools run by religious bodies
parochial school - A school run by the Roman Catholic faith
seminary - A school of any faith specifically designed to train ministers
yeshiva - A school for training rabbis
madrasa - A school for teaching Islam
environmental issue - All aspects of protection, damage, and condition of the ecosystem of the planet earth and its surroundings.
renewable energy - Environmental impact of renewable energy, including solar, wind, hydro, biomass and geothermal
conservation - Preservation of wilderness areas, flora and fauna, including species extinction
endangered species - Those species of wildlife in danger of disappearing, largely because of changes in environment, hunting, or weather
ecosystem - A system of plants, animals and bacteria interrelated in its physical/chemical environment
energy saving - Conservation of electrical, and other power sources
environmental politics - The debate on environmental policy
environmental pollution - Corruption of air, water, land etc. by harmful substances
air pollution - Solid or gaseous matter affecting the quality of air that we breathe
water pollution - Solids or liquids that corrupt the quality of water that could be used for drinking or irrigation
natural resources - Stories about the environmental issues related to the exploitation of natural resources for human use
land resources - That portion of a nation or state that is above water and available for development either for profit or for the general good of the public
parks - Areas set aside and developed for public enjoyment and recreation, including commercial development such as theme parks
forests - Open areas of trees either available for public enjoyment, or for commercial purposes
wetlands - Areas generally marshy and not either under water or dry land. Often related to aquifers for water quality and/or wildlife
mountains - Elevated land masses formed over the ages either by erosion, volcanic eruption, or movement of massive geographical formations called plates
rivers - Moving water areas bounded by land that extend from earth sources and meander through land areas to join with other water areas. In smaller forms they are creeks, rivulets, streams etc
oceans - Salt water masses separating continents or other major geographical masses. smaller forms are seas or lakes or ponds
wildlife - All forms of animal life that have not been domesticated
energy resources - Such resources as coal, gas, wind, sunlight etc., used to generate heat, electricity and power
nature - Taken as a whole the natural environment of flora and fauna
invasive species - Non-native plants, animals and other organisms that tend to take over native species
population - People and their growth and development within a natural setting
waste - Environmental impact of waste, including recycling efforts
water - Environmental issues about bodies of water, including oceans, lakes, streams and reservoirs, as well as ice, glaciers and forms of precipitation
global warming - All issues relating to global warming including temperature research, remote sensing on temperature trends, debate on global warming, ways to reduce emissions and carbon trading.
hazardous materials - Materials that are harmful to humans or animals if they are exposed to them. Includes radiation, poison gases, chemicals, heavy metals, PCBs, and certain plant products
environmental cleanup - Processes whereby contaminated areas are cleaned of hazardous materials so they can be inhabited again by either people or animals.
health - All aspects pertaining to the physical and mental welfare of human beings.
disease - Any harmful or destructive condition
communicable diseases - Diseases that can be transmitted from one person or animal to another
virus diseases - Diseases caused by infection within cells by viruses
AIDS - Acquired Immunity Deficiency Syndrome, an incurable disease caused by the human immunodeficiency virus
cancer - A serious and often fatal disease caused when normal cells mutate into tumours
heart disease - A degenerative and serious disease caused by narrowing of the arteries feeding the heart
alzheimer's disease - A disorder of the brain leading to dementia
animal diseases - Disorders affecting animals that do not necessarily endanger humans
plant diseases - Disorders affecting plants caused either by parasites or environmental factors
retrovirus - A family of RNA viruses such as those causing leukaemia and AIDS
epidemic and plague - An epidemic is a rapidly spreading condition in a community and a plague is usually a deadly disease of epidemic proportions
health treatment - In general treatment of diseases and other conditions to produce wellness
prescription drugs - Drugs that can be purchased only with a doctor's authorization
dietary supplements - Nutrients taken in addition to food to bolster health
diet - Controlled food consumption
medical procedure/test - Any of a variety of treatments such as stress tests, catheterization, blood tests, computerised axial tomography scan or magnetic resonance imaging
therapy - Treatment of physical, mental or medical conditions by non-surgical means
health organisations - Includes stories about specific health organizations, including professional associations, non-profits and international groups
medical research - Investigation into the causes and cures of diseases
medical staff - Doctors, nurses, interns and others in a medical facility
primary care physician - Patient's basic health care doctor - first point of call for all health related problems
health-workers union - Issues involving industry groups for doctors, nurses, health workers etc.
medicine - A substance used with the expectation that it will eliminate disease or illness
herbal - Treatment based on the use of herbs and other plants to cure or alleviate disease symptoms
holistic - Treatment of the whole person including mental and social factors rather than just the symptoms of the disease.
western - The practice of diagnosis, treatment and prevention of disease based on modern scientific research in the western hemisphere.
traditional Chinese - The practice of diagnosis, treatment and prevention of disease based on traditional methods developed in the orient.
preventative medicine - Substances used to prevent diseases or illnesses
vaccines - Medications designed to create immunity to diseases
injury - A traumatic condition of the human body caused usually by outside forces
hospital and clinic - Medical facilities for the treatment of illnesses and injury
government health care - Health care provided by national governments
medicare - A program of the U.S. government to provide health care to senior citizens
medicaid - A program of the U.S. government to provide health care to needy citizens of all ages
private health care - Health care provided by privately funded or insured organizations
healthcare policy - Health-related policy decisions including what different countries are doing regarding prescription drug policies, AIDS, psychiatric care, health care funding and related topics.
food safety - Issues relating to food cleanliness and contamination
medical specialisation - The different medical specialist areas.

geriatric - Research into aging and age-related issues including age-related illnesses, medical research, trends, geriatric medicine and related topics like age discrimination and health insurance for an ageing population.
pediatrics - Research and medicine specifically for the young - includes premature babies, infant care, childhood disease and treatment - also teen-related health and behaviour problems.

reproduction - Reproductive technologies like invitro fertilization and cloning as well as related debates. Sexual development matters and sexually transmitted diseases would also fall under this category.

genetics - The science and research into genetic-base disease and cures for disease. This would include proteomics (the study of what proteins are produced by which genes and what those proteins do), general genetics and stem-cell research.
obstetrics/gynecology - Specialty of female reproductive organs
medical service - Medical support for doctors, including blood tests and other medical tests on individuals, X-rays CAT scans MRIs etc.
physical fitness - The condition of a person's cardio-vascular and muscular health.
illness - Non-specific maladies such as stomach aches, headaches, flat feet, lumbago
mental illness - Those illnesses affecting the mind
eating disorder - Anorexia, bulimia, overeating and similar illnesses
obesity - A condition of body weight generally considered 20 percent above the norm for gender, age, height and bone structure
medical conditions - Various stages of disease, illness or injury
patient - Issues which affect population in general as attendees at hospitals or doctors' surgeries.
human interest - Lighter items about individuals, groups, animals or objects.
animal - Animals of all types
curiosity - Content of an unusual nature that can raise questions or amuse
people - Unusual content about people of all levels
advice - Letters and answers about personal problems that are publishable
celebrity - Celebrity news, i.e. Madonna has a baby, Elton John sues his accountants etc.
accomplishment - Achievements by individuals or groups, such as charitable fundraising, winning a competitive contest etc
human mishap - Stories arising from silly/stupid human errors e.g. like forgetting to tie one end of a bungee cord
fortune-telling - The forecasting of future events or the delineation of character by methods not ordinarily considered to have a rational basis
mystery - Something unexplained or unknown
society - Stories of well-known people
ceremony - Rituals of a non-religious nature such as dedications, wreath layings, ship launchings etc
death - The human interest aspects of the demise of a person
funeral - The ceremony to intern the remains of a person
estate bestowal - The distribution of the estate of a person according to their will and any disagreements between the heirs
memorial - Commemorative ceremony or object - plaque, statue etc - in remembrance of a person.
award and prize - Decorations, awards and prizes, including those given by the government.
record - Non-sport achievement by an individual or group that sets a new record, such as most books read, holding your breath longest
imperial and royal matters - Imperial and royal family members, including matters on legal systems.
plant - An organism of the kind exemplified by trees, shrubs, grasses, ferns, and mosses, typically growing in a permanent site
labour - Social aspects, organizations, rules and conditions affecting the employment of human effort for the generation of wealth or provision of services and the economic support of the unemployed.
apprentices - People who are in the work force at a learning level, serving under a master
collective contract - Usually written contracts covering a specific class of worker
contract issue-wages - Element of contracts and contract discussions centring on remuneration
contract issue-healthcare - Element of contracts and contract discussions centring on health care issues

contract issue-work rules - Element of contracts and contract discussions centring on rules affecting issues such as lunch and other breaks, work shifts, vacation scheduling, seniority, sick leave etc.
employment - Paid labour
labor market - A pool of people who are working or are seeking work
job layoffs - The reduction of a company's work force through dismissal because of changing economic factors
child labor - Employment of children, usually under the age of 18
occupations - Generally one's trade, profession or business although professions are usually such things as lawyers and doctors, and occupations are such as clerks or truckers
labour dispute - Differences of opinion about work conditions, pay, etc
labour legislation - Laws governing work and labour
retirement - The years after work
retraining - Providing a worker training in new skills when his old skills are no longer applicable
strike - A job action involving cessation of work
unemployment - Lack of paid work
unions - Groups established to represent bodies of workers
wage and pension - Parts of a salary divided for current income and future income

employee benefits - Either benefits provided to an employee by a company, such as pensions, health insurance; or monetary compensation paid by a government to the jobless usually called unemployment benefits
social security - FICA. Money paid by individual and companies into a government account to be paid out when that individual reaches a certain age
work relations - The give and take between management and labour
health and safety at work - Rules and procedures for guaranteeing the health of workers
advanced training - Additional training to enhance current skills
employer - The person who employs workers and pays the salaries and other benefits to workers
employee - A person who trades his time and talent for money and other benefits
lifestyle and leisure - Activities undertaken for pleasure, relaxation or recreation outside paid employment, including eating and travel.
game - Contests generally for ones amusement
Go - A strategic, deterministic Chinese board game played by alternately placing stones on a grid
chess - A game played on a chequered board with 16 pieces to each side with specific ranges of movement depending on their identity
bridge - A card game of four players who bet on the hands of each other, developed from Russian whist
shogi - A strategic board games which is native to Japan and is often called Japanese chess
gaming and lottery - Gambling, often involving selection of sets of numbers one expects to come up
gastronomy - The art of good eating
organic foods - Food which is grown using no artificial fertilizers or chemical compounds
hobby - Various types of activities for amusement, such as collecting stamps, building models, quilting, crafts
DIY - DIY - do it yourself. Normally the construction, repair or maintenance of residential property by an amateur
shopping - Consumer purchasing and related trends, but not the business aspects of retailing
gardening - The non-commercial aspects of landscaping, growing plants, trees and other vegetation that gives pleasure to the gardener and others
holiday or vacation - Leisure travel to a single location and/or country over a short period of time
tourism - Leisure travel involving visits to a number of locations and/or countries over an extended period of time, often as part of an organized group
travel and commuting - Transport options, travel networks, commuting, car pooling and business travel
traffic - Traffic reports and/or warnings
club and association - Organizations joined by individuals because of similar interests
lifestyle (house and home) - Unique culture of ones own home
leisure (general) - Activities carried out in ones' spare time
public holiday - A day or days set off for celebration
hunting - An activity involving the use of weapons or traps for the capturing of animals
fishing - An activity involving the use of baits, lures, weapons and traps for the capture of aquatic species
auto trends - The evolution of the automobile
adventure - Expeditions, daring feats, exploration, record-breaking, risk-associated events
beauty - Issues relating to improving one's appearance and attractiveness, including reviews of beauty products
consumer issue - Shopping, products for the home, relevant surveys, product recalls
wedding - The marriage ceremony and the events that surround it - showers, rehearsal, parties, honeymoon, etc.
politics - Local, regional, national and international exercise of power, or struggle for power, and the relationships between governing bodies and states.
defence - Anything involving the defence of one's own country
veterans affairs - Care and provision for those who served in the military
national security - The philosophy of securing a nation and its borders, as well as the well being of its citizens
security measures - Means of making a nation, a state, a building or a person secure from harm and outside interference.
armed Forces - Those employed by a government to conduct war, or to enforce the security of a nation
military equipment - Equipment issued to members of the armed forces
firearms - Anything that uses an explosive in a directed manner to propel an object that can maim or kill
biological and chemical weapons - Devices using biological agents, or chemical mixtures to disable, maim or kill an opponent
missile systems - Anything that propels an inert, explosive, biological or chemical object through the air with the aim of disabling, maiming or killing an opponent.
nuclear weapons - Weapons that use controlled radioactivity from the decay of certain elements to disable, maim or kill an opponent
diplomacy - The use of verbal and written skills for persuading others to your point of view
summit - Includes meetings of leaders, foreign and finance ministers from the Group of Eight major nations and Group of Seven industrialized nations.
international relations - Non-violent relations between nations through negotiation, treaty, or personal meetings
peace negotiations - Negotiations intended to bring an end to a conflict
alliances - Coalitions of like-minded groups formed to present a stronger force against any challenges
election - The selection of representatives by the casting of votes
political candidates - Individuals who are chosen to stand for office
political campaigns - Campaigns for public office
campaign finance - The money that makes campaigns for public office possible
national elections - Choosing individuals for government at a national level
regional elections - Choosing individuals for government at a regional level
local elections - Choosing individuals for government at the basic level, whether city, village or county
voting - The act of selecting an individual you would like to represent your interests in government
poll - Periodic measurement of a political candidate's standing with the public
european elections - Choosing individuals for a body which is at a higher level than national government, e.g. European parliament
primary - Preliminary elections on a local or regional basis leading up to a regional or national election
espionage and intelligence - Covert collection of information
foreign aid - Help provided by one nation to another
economic sanction - Punitive actions taken by one country against another including trade restrictions, embargoes etc.
government - The system for ruling a country
civil and public service - The paid service by civilians for the government, and the often non-paid service of individuals for the benefit of others (public service)
safety of citizens - Government policies to protect the well being of its citizens
think tank - Group that undertakes political research and issue position papers, recommendations etc
national government - The ruling body of a nation
executive (government) - That portion of a ruling body involving the overall operation of government
heads of state - Symbolic or actual chief representative of a nation, such as royalty, or president or emir, for example
government departments - Divisions of a government that concentrate on specific areas such as health, welfare, economy or war
public officials - Individuals, usually elected, who are in public service or commonly in the public eye.

ministers (government) - Heads of various government departments at one level, also known as secretaries. At another level they form a legislative body. The chief minister is either prime minister or premier.
public employees - People employed by a government at all levels
privatisation - The privatisation of state-owned companies or property
nationalisation - State takeover of private companies or property
impeachment - The process of bringing a public official before a tribunal to answer charges of wrongdoing
human rights - Rights entitled to be enjoyed by all citizens universally
local authority - Authorities at city, county state or borough level
parliament - The collective body of elected officials representing the people
upper house - Senior chamber of a legislative body
lower house - The lower chamber of a legislative body
parties and movements - Covers both formally recognized and informal political associations
non government organizations (NGO) - Groups officially outside of government that lobby, demonstrate or campaign on a wide range of issues such as economics, environment healthcare etc.
refugee - A person seeking shelter in another country because of some fear of persecution in his own country
regional authority - Government bodies at levels encompassing more than one jurisdiction, e.g. the Delaware River Basin Commission
state budget and tax - The national budget as promulgated by the government
public finance - The money of government used for paying for public programs and services and public debt
treaty and international organisation-DEPRECATED - NA
international relations-DEPRECATED - NA
peace negotiations-DEPRECATED - NA
alliances-DEPRECATED - NA
constitution - Usually a written document setting forth the operations of a government and the rights of the citizens therein
interior policy - Government policies affecting internal affairs of a country
data protection - Efforts to protect personal information in either written, oral or electronic form
housing and urban planning - Systematic planning of urban and suburban areas and the housing within those areas
pension and welfare - Government policies affecting the well being of its citizens through unemployment benefits, state pensions and other similar payments
personal weapon control - Government control of personal ownership of firearms and other offensive weapons, including control of weapons used for sports through licenses and other means
indigenous people - Government policies toward indigenous peoples
personal data collection - The collection, by government or other entities of information on individuals
planning inquiries - Public hearings or planning inquiries on proposed constructions, e.g. Construction of water driven power station in a National Park.
migration - Movement of one body of persons from one place to another
citizens initiative and recall - Political suggestions by non-government officials for corrective action, or for changes in existing rules and regulations
referenda - Political proposals, laws and actions suggested by non-government officials to be voted on by the entire voting body
nuclear policy - Government policies as regards to use of nuclear fuels for power production or weapons
lobbying - The attempt by non-government bodies and individual to affect the outcome of legislation through verbal, or other, persuasion
regulatory policy and organisation - The rules and bodies, both national and international, that govern conflict of interest and good practice regulations.

censorship - Attempts by any group to control freedoms of speech, religion, and ideas distributed in print, graphics, cyberspace and other ways. Does not include official standards such as cinema ratings, advertising and broadcast standards.
politics (general) - The art or science of participating in the affairs of government, a state of political party
political systems - Systems designed to provide order to government
democracy - Government in which the people hold the power either directly, or through elected officials.
political development - The creation and rise of political systems and the history of the people and nations that are associated with those systems.

freedom of the press - Mass media rights and freedoms, pressure and intimidation of the journalists, censorship in mass media, activities of government bodies, journalistic associations and/or organizations and other NGOs in regards to press freedom

freedom of religion - Religious rights and freedoms, pressure and intimidation of the believers, censorship in mass media, activities of government bodies, journalistic associations and/or organizations and other NGOs in regards to freedom of belief and p
treaty - A treaty (as defined by the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties) is a written agreement between international entities that is binding under international law.
international organisation - Includes organisations with members and functions that cross international borders, and may include intergovernmental organisations of sovereign nations.
religion and belief - All aspects of human existence involving theology, philosophy, ethics and spirituality.
cult and sect - Offshoots of established religious bodies, or small narrow-focused group promulgated by one or two individuals
belief (faith) - The established beliefs of an individuals religion
unificationism - The belief system of members of the Unification Church established by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

scientology - Believe that man is a spiritual being endowed with abilities well beyond those which he normally envisages; he's able to solve his own problems, accomplish his goals and gain lasting happiness.
freemasonry - A secret international society based on the principles of brotherhood, charity and mutual aid
religion-DEPRECATED - NA
christianity-DEPRECATED - NA
islam-DEPRECATED - NA
judaism-DEPRECATED - NA
buddhism-DEPRECATED - NA
hinduism-DEPRECATED - NA
church (organisation)-DEPRECATED - NA
religious facilities-DEPRECATED - NA
values - Personal levels of social behaviour
ethics - A system of beliefs about acceptable behaviour
corrupt practices - Any action which is harmful to others
church and state relations - The legal and social division between religious institutions and the affairs of state
philosophy - Different thoughts about the way the world works
christianity - Those that use Jesus Christ and his teachings as their centre of belief
protestant - General term for christian churches and religious communities which developed through the reformation in the 16th century
lutheran - Christians who follow the teaching of reformer Martin Luther
reformed - Christians who follow the teaching of reformers Johannes Calvin and Ulrich Zwingli
anglican - Members of the worldwide anglican communion which started in the 16th century in England as a breakaway church from the roman catholic church
methodist - Followers of John and Charles Wesley who tried to reform the Church of England in the 18th century and turned into a separate church
baptist - Members of a christian church which only baptises adults who truly believe in Christ
mennonite - Members of a 16th century christian church which is against military service and baptising infants
mormon - Members of a religious community which believes in the "Book of Mormon" and the revelations of founder M.J. Smith
roman catholic - Biggest christian church worldwide tracing its origins back to Jesus Christ
old catholic - Members of a catholic church which started in 1870 and denies the dogma of the infallibility of the pope

orthodoxy - Eastern rite churches which are characterised by their continuity with the apostolic church, their liturgy and their territorial churches, mainly in eastern and south-eastern Europe and the Middle East
salvation army - Christian community organised in a military fashion which does missionary and social work
islam - Those who use Allah and his teachings as their centre of belief
judaism - A group believing in one god, basing their beliefs on written scriptures and the Talmud, including the first coming of the Messiah
buddhism - A major Asian religion founded by Buddha in the 6th century BC in India and preaching that right thinking and self denial will lead to a divine state without desire
hinduism - A religious and social system, believing in a caste system with the Brahmans the highest and untouchables the lowest.
religious festival or holiday - Holy day or day of observance in a religion which sometimes is a public holiday as well
christmas - Christian festival in commemorating the birth of Jesus Christ
easter - Christian festival in commemorating the resurrection of Jesus Christ
pentecost - Christian festival, celebrated on the 50th day after Easter commemorating the descent of the Holy Spirit
ramadan - Holy month of fasting in Islam
yom kippur - Most solemn of Jewish religious holidays, observed on the 10th day of the lunar month of tishri (in the course of September and October, when Jews seek reconciliation with god
religious leader - Person or persons who have a ritual, juridical or otherwise leading role in their respective church or religion
pope - Head of the roman catholic church worldwide
nature religion - Worship of natural elements like fire, water, trees, mountains
taoism - Indigenous religio-philosophical tradition that has shaped Chinese life for more than 2000 years
shintoism - Indigenous religious beliefs and practices of Japan. The word Shinto came into use in order to distinguish indigenous Japanese beliefs from Buddhism.
sikhism - The religion of an Indian group, combining Hindu and Islamic elements, founded in the Punjab (or Panjab) in the late 15th century AD by Guru Nanak.

jainism - A religion of India that teaches a path to spiritual purity and enlightenment through a disciplined mode of life founded upon the tradition of ahimsa, non-violence to all living creatures. It began in the 7th-5th century BC.
parsasm - A religion in India following the Iranian prophet Zoroaster, mainly in Bombay, but also in Karachi (Pakistan).
confucianism - The way of life propagated by Confucius in the 6th-5th century BC and followed by the Chinese people for more than 2000 years. Its influence has extended to Korea, Japan, and Vietnam.
religious text - Scriptures holy or important for a church or religion
bible - Sacred scriptures of Christianity consisting of the old and new testament
qur'an - Holy book of Islam
torah - Holy scriptures of Judaism
interreligious dialogue - Any form of communication between religions
religious event - News regarding a religious event but not a festival or holiday
catholic convention - A catholic convention
protestant convention - A protestant convention
ritual - Established religious rituals such as mass, baptism, prayer meetings
concordat - Treaty between the Holy See and another country for the regulation of ecclesiastical affairs in the territory of the latter
ecumenism - Relations between christian churches
science and technology - All aspects pertaining to human understanding of nature and the physical world and the development and application of this knowledge
applied science - Stories about putting scientific knowledge to practical uses in the fields of the medical sciences, agriculture, domestic sciences as well as trades and crafts
physics - The study of the properties and changes of matter
chemistry - The study of the composition and reaction of substances
cosmology - Study of the organization and structure of the universe
particle physics - The study of elementary particles and atomic nuclei through the use of high-energy particles
engineering - Stories about putting scientific knowledge to practical uses in the fields of civil, electrical, mechanical and chemical engineering
material science - The study of materials used in manufacturing
human science - Sociology, psychology, anthropology and political science
social sciences - The study of people living in groups, as families, tribes and communities
history - The study of human events of the past
psychology - The study of the human mind and mental and emotional processes
sociology - The study of human social relations, organization and change
anthropology - The study of human beings in groups or societies
natural science - Astronomy, astrophysics, physics, chemistry, earth sciences, palaeontology, biological sciences, botany and zoology, as well as mathematics
geology - The study of Earth's physical processes
paleontology - The study of ancient animals
geography - The study of the surface of Earth and its political divisions
botany - The study of plants
zoology - The study of animals
physiology - The study of vital processes of living organisms
astronomy - The study of the stars and planets
biology - The study of living organisms
philosophical science - Philosophy, logic and ethics, among others
research - Methodical investigation of events, procedures etc to explain why they occur, or to find solutions for problems
survey - Examination of public attitudes on various subjects or issues, such as the quality of goods, the value of services etc.
scientific exploration - Methodical land, sea and space journeys to discover new information about them
space programme - The government's organized effort for the exploration of outer space and the bodies therein
science (general) - Establishing and systematizing information about nature and the physical world through observation, experimentation and hypothesis
technology (general) - The study of the practical or industrial arts, and applied sciences such as physics, hydrodynamics and thermodynamics
rocketry - The development of rockets
laser - The development and use of light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation
standards - The rules, national and international, that govern science and technology. These might include international standards setting for equipment and interference standards.
animal science - Science involving animals
micro science - The multi-disciplinary areas of nanotechnology and Micro-Electrical Mechanical Systems.
marine science - The multi-disciplinary research areas involving the worlds' waterways and oceans. This could include hyper-spectral sensing of ice flows, fisheries studies and underwater research.
weather science - All scientific aspects of the weather and climate.

electronics - The branch of engineering or physics concerned with the controlled flow of electrons or other carriers of electric charges, especially in semiconductor devices, including the design, manufacture, and maintenance of electronic devices

identification technology - Includes biometrics, new computer-based identification cards, retinal scans, face scanning and mobile augmented reality systems (MARS) and other ways technology can identify individuals. Also technology vs. the privacy of perso
mathematics - The study of quantities and shapes and their symbolic relationships.
biotechnology - Manipulating natural organisms for scientific, medical or agricultural purposes
agricultural research and technology - Pertaining to the growing of crops and management of farm animals
nanotechnology - Manipulating objects at the molecular scale
IT/computer sciences - The study and design of computer systems and networks.
scientific institutions - Institutions that carry out or govern scientific work (e.g. National Academy of Arts and Sciences )
social issue - Aspects of the behaviour of humans affecting the quality of life.
addiction - The habitual and often uncontrollable use of harmful substances such as alcohol, tobacco and pharmaceuticals or drugs
charity - Philanthropic giving
demographics - The study of people and here they live and how they interact
population and census - Population is the number of people in a geographical region and census is the process of counting them
immigration - Movement of individuals from one country to the other
illegal immigrants - Movement of individuals from one country to the other by illicit means
emigrants - People who leave their country of origin, their relationship with their country of origin and their association with fellow emigrants
disabled - Being incapacitated either physically, emotionally or mentally
euthanasia (also includes assisted suicide) - Voluntary death with the aid of another
suicide - Death by one's own hand
family - A group of individuals related by blood or marriage
parent and child - Two or more individuals with a hierarchical familial relationship
adoption - A legal process of bringing a child with no supporting parents into a supportive union
marriage - The union of two individuals who pledge fidelity, respect and support for each other
divorce - The process by which a marriage is dissolved
sex - The classification of individuals as either male or female. Or conjugal relationship between two individuals.
courtship - Preliminaries of wooing and winning a partner
family planning - Conscious decisions and efforts involving reproduction
health insurance - Insurance covering extraordinary medical costs
homelessness - Lacking a fixed place of residence
minority group - A group of people classified by race, language, religion or other characteristic numerically smaller than others of the same classification
gays and lesbians - Those that consider themselves attracted to their same gender in an erotic or sensual or similar way.
national or ethnic minority - Groups of people that form a minority on ethnic or national basis, their status, problems and relations to the majority
pornography - Audio or visual depictions of various sex related acts considered outside accepted community standards
poverty - Having insufficient resources to provide for basic services to oneself or family
prostitution - Sex for sale, either male or female, and those who profit from it
racism - Harmful attitudes toward another group based on racial differences
welfare - Generally government help for those in need of food, housing health and other services
abortion - Usually the planned disruption of the process of reproduction of human life
missing person - A person who is not where they are expected to be for a period of time
missing due to hostilities - People, both civilian and military, missing during or after hostilities
long term care - Extensive health care because of serious illness or disability
juvenile delinquency - Incidents involving perpetrators who are minors.
nuclear radiation victims - Includes antinuclear movements and compensation for atomic blast victims.
slavery - The involuntary servitude, outside of legal incarceration for statuary criminal offences, of men, women and children, including involuntary unpaid labour, coerced actions, child labour

abusive behaviour - The maltreatment of one or more individuals by others through dehumanizing treatment including sexual or mental abuse, deprivation of sensory abilities, deprivation of physical needs, physical mistreatment including beatings, and other
death and dying - Dying is the route to death. Death is the state you are in when there are no signs that you can function as a human being either physically or mentally
people - Individuals as a whole, sometimes broken down into various classes, such as indigenous people, people of class etc
children - Immature people, usually up to the age of puberty
infants - Those people from birth until ages of one or two, usually when they begin walking
teen-agers - People aged 13 to 19 years of age
adults - People aged 20 and above
senior citizens - People aged 60 or 65 and older
social issues (general) - Issues affecting a number of individuals in their daily lives like housing, food, education, personal relationships
social conditions - Conditions under which people live in terms of housing, water supply, availability of education
social problems - Issues affecting the lives of individuals such as housing, education nutrition, communication etc
discrimination - Denial of services to one or more people because of race, colour, sexual identity, religion, political beliefs etc
social services - Government supported programs to improve the well-being of individuals or groups of individuals
death penalty policies - National or international polices regarding death sentences
ordnance clearance - The removal or neutralization of ordnance such as landmines or cluster bombs, remaining after a war or armed conflict
reconstruction - The reconstruction of economy, infrastructure and property, as well as life in general, after a war or natural disaster
sport - Competitive exercise involving physical effort. Organizations and bodies involved in these activities.
aero and aviation sport - Parachuting, freefall (parapente, delta-plane), gliding, aerostat, motorised flight (airplane, ultra light craft, helicopter)
parachuting - Parachuting competitions
sky diving - Parachuting competitions involving sky-diving
alpine skiing - Skiing downhill on snow-covered slopes as fast as possible. The slopes contain intermediate gates which are spaced according to the discipline involved
downhill - Skiing at top speed down a steep slope with interspersed turns but no gates. The fastest wins.
giant slalom - Skiing down a slope, but with more turns and bends than in super-G skiing. The fastest wins.
super G - Skiing down a steep slope, but with more turns and bends than in the downhill. The fastest wins.
slalom - Skiers must zig-zag their way down a slope with closely positioned gates which they must negotiate. It is run over two legs with the combined fastest winning.
combined - Race, usually competed over two days that combines a downhill leg and a slalom leg rewarding the most complete skiers. Combined fastest time wins.

American football - Team ball game that opposes two teams that have attack sections and defence sections. Each attack goes up against the other defence and attempts to move an oval-shaped ball down the field and into the end-zone to mark a touchdown and e
(US) National Football League (NFL) (North American) - The association of professional American football teams
CFL - The Canadian Football League (CFL), also known as Ligue Canadienne de Football (LCF), is a professional league located entirely in Canada that plays Canadian football.
AFL-DEPRECATED - The American Football League (AFL) was a professional league of American football that operated from 1960 to 1969. In 1970, the AFL merged with the National Football League.
archery - Archers use bows and arrows to aim at targets 1.22 metres in diameter which are on average 70 metres distant.

FITA / Outdoor target archery - The competition is held outdoors on an open (flat) field, at various fixed distances. The archery competition in the Olympic Games is a part of the FITA outdoor target archery program.
crossbow shooting - Shooting with crossbow on targets from different distances
athletics, track and field - Competitions involving foot races, jumping and throwing which can be on a track inside a stadium or on outside roads
100 m - Running over a distance of 100 metres with the fastest time winning
200 m - Running over a distance of 200 metres with the fastest time winning
400 m - Running over a distance of 400 metres with the fastest time winning
800 m - Running over a distance of 800 metres with the fastest time winning
1000 m - Running over a distance of 1000 metres with the fastest time winning
1500 m - Running over a distance of 1000 metres with the fastest time winning
mile - Running over a distance of one mile with the fastest time winning
2000 m - Running over a distance of 2000 metres with the fastest time winning
3000 m - Running over a distance of 3000 metres with the fastest time winning
5000 m - Running over a distance of 5000 metres with the fastest time winning
10,000 m - Running over a distance of 10,000 metres with the fastest time winning
20 km - Walking over a distance of 20 km on public roads with the fastest time winning
one hour - Walking as far as possible in the time of one hour
25000 - Walking over a distance of 25km with the fastest time winning
30000 - Walking over a distance of 30kms with the fastest time winning
110 m hurdles - Race consisting of covering 110 metres as fast as possible while jumping over 10 hurdles placed on the track
400 m hurdles - Race consisting of covering 400 metres as fast as possible while jumping over 10 hurdles placed on the track
