3000 m steeplechase - Race consisting of covering 3000 metres as fast as possible while jumping over 28 hurdles which are 91/4 centimetres high and seven water obstacles
high jump - Competitors jump as high as possible over a bar which is raised each time they clear the height. The highest clearance wins.
pole vault - Competitors use a flexible pole to propel themselves feet-first into the air and clear a bar which is raised higher at each round of jumps.
long jump - Competitors build up speed over a short sprint and them attempt to jump as far forward as they can from a given point into sand trap. The longest jump wins.
triple jump - Competitors build up speed over a short sprint and then attempt to jump as far forward as they can using a hop, skip and a jump technique. The longest jump wins.
shot put - Competitors stand in a circle with a 2.13 metres diameter and attempt to throw a metal ball weighing 7.26 kg for men and 4kg for women as far as possible. The longest throw wins.

discus throw - Competitors stand in a netted circle with a 2.50 metres diameter and with a turning motion attempt to throw a discus weighing 2kg for men and 1kg for women as far as possible. The longest throw wins.

hammer throw - Competitors throw a hammer consisting of a metal ball, chain and handle as far as they can from a netted circle which is 2.13 metres in diameter. The hammer weighs 7.26 kg for men and 4 kg for women.
javelin throw - Competitors in a specially-designated throwing area attempt to fling a spear-like javelin as far as possible. The javelin weighs 800 grammes for men and 600 grammes for women.
decathlon - Individual men's competition which involves accumulating points in 10 different disciplines over two days
4x100 m - Team race involving four runners each covering 100 metres.
4x200 m - Team race involving four runners each covering 200 metres.
4x400 m - Team race involving four runners each covering 400 metres.
4x800 m - Team race involving four runners each covering 800 metres.
4x1500 m - Team race involving four runners each covering 1500 metres.
walk 1 h - One-hour long race where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
walk 2 h - Two-hour long walking race where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
10 km walk - Walking race over 10 kilometres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
15 km walk - Walking race over 15 kilometres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
20 km walk - Walking race over 20 kilometres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
30 km walk - Walking race over 30 kilometres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
50 km walk - Walking race over 50 kilometres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
100 m hurdles - Sprint over a distance of 100 metres with competitors having to clear 10 hurdles placed in their way.
5 km walk - Walking race over 5 kilometres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
heptathlon - Individual women's competition involving seven separate disciplines over two days. 1st day - 100m hurdles, high-jump, shot-putt, 200 metres. 2nd day - long-jump, javelin, 800 metres.
1500 m walk - Walking race over 1500 metres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
2000 m walk - Walking race over 2000 metres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
3000 m walk - Walking race over 3000 metres where competitors must maintain at least one foot in contact with the ground and are not allowed to run.
50 m - Short sprint race over 50 metres with the fastest time winning.
50 m hurdles - Short sprint race over 50 metres interspersed with hurdles.
50 yards - Short sprint race over 50 yards with the fastest time winning.
50 yard hurdles - Short sprint race over 50 yards interspersed with hurdles.
60 m - Short sprint race over 60 metres with the fastest time winning.
60 m hurdles - Short sprint race over 60 metres interspersed with hurdles.
60 yards - Short sprint race over 60 yards with the fastest time winning.
60 yard hurdles - Short sprint race over 60 yards interspersed with hurdles.
100 yards - Sprint race over 100 yards with the fastest time winning.
100 yard hurdles - Sprint race over 100 yards interspersed with hurdles.
300 m - Race over 300 metres with the fastest time winning.
300 yards - Race over 300 yards with the fastest time winning.
440 yards - Race over 440 yards with the fastest time winning.
500 m - Race over 500 metres with the fastest time winning.
500 yards - Race over 500 yards with the fastest time winning.
600 m - Race over 600 metres with the fastest time winning.
600 yards - Race over 600 yards with the fastest time winning.
880 yards - Race over 880 yards with the fastest time winning.
1000 yards - Race over 1000 yards with the fastest time winning.
2 miles - Race over two miles with the fastest time winning.
3 miles - Race over three miles with the fastest time winning.
6 miles - Race over six miles with the fastest time winning.
4x1 mile - Team Relay race with four runners on each team running for one mile.
pentathlon - Only indoor, 60m hurdles, high jump, shot put, long jump, 800 m

badminton - Two players or two teams of two compete by hitting a shuttlecock weighing approximately five grams over a high net. The aim for each player/team is to prevent the shuttlecock landing on their side of the court.
baseball - A game between two teams of nine played on an enclosed ground. The team which scores the most points wins. A point is scored when a player runs around the ground marked out by four bases.
Major League Baseball (North American Professional) - American League - Baseball league comprising 14 teams.
Major League Baseball (North American Professional) - National League - Baseball league comprising 16 teams.
Major League Baseball (North American Professional) - Special (e.g. All-Star, World Series) - Baseball competition other than the World Series.
rubberball baseball - Sometimes called ''soft baseball,'' the game is played with a rubber baseball of varying degrees of hardness depending upon the age and level of the players.
Major League Baseball Playoffs - Consists of several rounds of play to determine representatives to the U.S.-based World Series
World Series - U.S.-based annual series of games between the top two teams of Major League Baseball to determine the overall champion
basketball - Game played between two teams of five - points are scored by placing the large inflated ball into a net fixed on a ring 3.05m above the ground.

National Basketball Association (North American Professional) - The NBA is the umbrella organisation running professional basketball in the United States. The NBA is made up of two conferences (east and west), four divisions (Atlantic and Central for the
professional - Women general - Women's professional league
Swiss netball - Similar to Basketball. Basket without a board. Mainly executed by women
German netball - Same as Swiss Netball, but with specific German rules
Dutch netball - Same as Swiss Netball, but with specific Dutch rule
biathlon - A combination of cross country skiing and target shooting in a pursuit format.
7.5 km - Timed cross country skiing race. Competitors set off at 30sec intervals for three circuits totalling 7.5km.
10 km - Sprint races for men, pursuit for women.
15 km - Individual women's race in sprint format staged over three laps with competitors setting off at intervals of a minute.
20 km - Individual men's race in sprint format staged over five laps with competitors setting off at intervals of a minute.
4x7.5 km relay - Teams consisting of four biathletes with each team covering a distance of 7.5km with two rounds of target shooting.
12.5 km pursuit - The start is determined by the results from the sprint. A race held over five laps with target shooting (standing or prone)
billiards, snooker and pool - A game played on a flat table covered with a cloth (baize) where players hit balls according to specific rules using a wooden cue.

8 ball - A game using 15 balls and a white. The first player aims to pot the balls numbered 1-7 (solids) with the second player potting balls 9-15 (stripes). After that the first player to pot the black wins.
9 ball - A game played with nine balls numbered 1-9, and a white. On each turn the player must hit the lowest numbered ball.

14.1 - A player nominates the ball he is attempting to pot and into which pocket. He collects points for each successful hit. He continues until he makes a mistake. Before hitting the 15th ball, the 14 reds are set up again in the triangle.
continuous-DEPRECATED - NA
other-DEPRECATED - NA

snooker - Two players using a cue and a white ball to "sink" other coloured balls in a correct order on a baize table and to cause an opponent to miss-hit by positioning the white ball in an inappropriate place - snookering.

bobsleigh - In bobsleigh two or four persons race down a course sitting in a sled that consists of a main hull, a frame, two axles and sets of runners. The total time of all heats in a competition is added together to determine the winner.
two-man sled - race consisting of a team of two competitors
four-man sled - race consisting of a team of four competitors
bowling - A game in which a player scores points by trying to knock down ten 'pins' using a ball - if unsuccessful the player has a second attempt. A game consists of ten frames.
bowls and petanque - A game in which players throw bowls at a target, the winner being the player who lands closest.

boxing - Combat sport in which two men/women fight using only their fists covered by padded gloves in a square ring measuring 6m a side. The fight is usually split into 12 rounds of three minutes each.
super-heavyweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
heavyweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
cruiserweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
light-heavyweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
super-middleweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
middleweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
light-middleweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
welterweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
light-welterweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
lightweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
super-featherweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
featherweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
super-bantamweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
bantamweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
super-flyweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
flyweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
light flyweight - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
straw - Weight category in boxing which varies according to the federation
IBF - International boxing federation
WBA - World boxing association
WBC - World boxing council
WBO - World boxing organisation
French boxing - Combat sport in which kicking with all parts of the feet are permitted and punching with the front of the fist is also allowed
Thai boxing - Form of boxing involving punches with fists, feet, knees, elbows and legs.
canoeing and kayaking - races in either 'white' or 'dead' water
Slalom - White water course set out with gates consisting of two poles suspended vertically over the water. Competitors must negotiate the gates or face penalties
200 m - race held over 200m
500 m - race held over 500m
1000 m - race held over 1000m
K1 - an enclosed boat with the competitor sitting on a fixed seat for one person using a double bladed paddle
K2 - an enclosed boat with the competitor sitting on a fixed seat for two people using double bladed paddles.
K4 - an enclosed boat with the competitor sitting on a fixed seat for four people using double bladed paddles.
C1 - One-seater canoe (open boat with competitor using a single bladed paddle.
C2 - Two-seater canoe (open boat) - competitors use a single bladed paddle.
C4 - Four-seater canoe (open boat) with each competitor using a single bladed paddle.
canoe sailing - A race involving a canoe equipped with a sail.
pontoniering - Team sport, military tradition, similar to canoe regatta, in boats
climbing - mountain sports
mountaineering - Alpine climbing
sport climbing - Sport climbing as a special category

parents.item: on an artificial wall with time measurement

item.name: cricket - Ball sport involving two teams of 11 players, balls, bats and wickets. The aim is to score as many runs as possible, and to get the opposing team 'out'. A 'run' involves a player running between two wickets. The opposing team try to get their ri

curling - A game played on ice with large flat round stones. A player throws the stone, aiming at a target. Team mates of the player who has thrown the stone can sweep the ice in front of the stone to help smooth its path towards the target.
icestock sport - Similar to curling, played on targets on ice, different stones with straight handle and different rules, played in alpine countries
cycling - A race over a given distance on bicycles.
track - A race staged on a track in a velodrome
pursuit - Two cyclists or teams set off from midway down opposite straights and try to make up the gap between them.
Olympic sprint - Qualifying race held over 200m. From the quarter-finals two cyclists go head-to-heads. By teams races consist of three cyclists from different countries.
sprint - Races between two cyclists over two or three laps, with a timed sprint finish over the last 200m.

Keirin - Sprint between six cyclists where a pacemaker on a moped gradually increases the pace over the first 1400m. When the pacemaker leaves the track the race develops into a sprint finish over the final 6-700m.
points race - Cyclists aim to complete the highest number of laps. Bonus points are picked up in intermediate sprints held every 2500m.
Madison race - A points race by teams comprising two cyclists in relay-format.
500 m time trial - Individual race against the clock over 500m for women.
1 km time trial - Individual race over 1000m against the clock for men.
one hour - Competitors aim to complete as many kilometres as possible in one hour.
road race - Road race with all the competitor starting en masse.
road time trial - A race or stage against the clock with each cyclist setting off individually.
staging race - A race disputed by teams with the classifications determined by the combined times over a day.
cyclo-cross - Staged on various surfaces - earth, grass, sand or tarmac.
Vtt - Mountain bikes
Vtt-cross - An endurance race on mountain bikes around a 10km circuit over various terrain and with different degrees of slopes. Competitors are not allowed any exterior help.
Vtt-downhill - Individual mountain bike race against the clock staged on a downhill circuit featuring obstacles.
bi-crossing - A race where competitors have to cover a circuit with obstacles as quickly as possible.
trial - A timed race in which competitors on mountain bikes must negotiate tricky terrain and obstacles without putting their feet down.
artistic cycling - Individual or teams on one or two bicycles in an arena. Points are awarded by a jury.

cycle ball - Competitive team sport using bicycles. One team against another with two persons per team. The aim is for competitors to move the ball using the front and rear wheels without letting their feet touch the ground.
dancing - Dancing competition where couples are judged on technique and interpretation.
diving - Competitors dive off a fixed or spring board and are assessed by seven judges giving marks up to ten for their acrobatic moves.
10 m platform - Divers take off from a ten metre high platform.

10 m platform synchronised - Two competitors from the same team dive off at the same time from separate platforms. As well as being judged on the standard criteria they are also awarded marks for synchronisation.
3 m springboard - Divers dive from a three-metre high springboard.

3 m springboard synchronised - Two competitors from the same team dive off at the same time from separate three-metre high springboards. As well as being judged on the standard criteria they are also awarded marks for synchronisation.
subaquatics - Sports like hockey held under water
scuba diving - Diving into different depths, with time measurement
equestrian - Sport involving a horse and rider.
three-day event - Equestrian event involving three disciplines - Dressage, cross-country and show jumping.
dressage - A rider is judged on a series of moves at three different paces - walk, trot and gallop.
jumping - A rider and horse attempt to jump a series of obstacles in an enclosed arena against the clock.
cross country - Equestrian event held on a designated circuit in the countryside featuring artificial and natural obstacles.
fencing - Combat sport using a sword or foil.
epee - category of fencing using a weapon with a triangular cross-section blade and a large bell guard.
foil - category of fencing using a weapon with a rectangular cross-section blade and a small bell guard.
sabre - a fencing weapon with a flat blade and knuckle guard used with cutting or thrusting moves.
field Hockey - A ball sport involving two teams of 11 players using curved sticks. The aim is to score as many goals as possible.
roll hockey - Team sport similar to ice hockey, executed on 4 wheel roller skates with sticks and a ball

figure Skating - To obtain the best marks possible from nine judges who award scores after two prepared sections - both skated to music - during which competitors must attempt to achieve the greatest possible harmony between artistic flair and technical p
singles - The individual events comprise a short program which counts for 33.3% of the score, and the free skate which is worth 66.7%.
pairs - The pairs event comprise a short program which counts for 33.3% of the score, and the free skate which is worth 66.7%.
ice dance - Takes place over three days with, in order, two compulsory dances, the original dance (2min 30sec) and the free dance (4min).
freestyle Skiing - Competitors perform a series of breathtaking acrobatic leaps from a prepared jump. Combined with moguls, jumps and ski ballet.
moguls - Contestants attack a heavily moguled slope, performing technically challenging turns and jumps, while maintaining the most direct line from the top to the bottom of the hill.
aerials - Competitors perform a series of aerial twists and turns from a prepared jump.
artistic skiing - Competitors perform a series of artistic moves (jumps and twists) all set to music. The use of ski poles is permitted.
golf - Competitors attempt to hit a small white ball with different clubs around a course of 18 holes varying in distance. The object is to make the fewest strokes possible.
gymnastics - A sport consisting of a variety of disciplines in which gymnasts perform artistic and acrobatic moves on different apparatus. There are 6 disciplines for men and 4 for women.
floor exercise - A gymnastics floor exercise on a 12m/sq matt.
vault - gymnasts propel themselves by jumping on a trampoline after running quickly down a 25m lane
pommel horse - Gymnasts perform an uninterrupted swing motion over a handled horse using balance and strength.
uneven bars - Gymnasts run through an airborne routine swinging around and between the uneven bars.
parallel bars - Gymnasts swing and turn with guile and grace around the parallel bars.
horizontal bar - Gymnasts turn, spin and perform pirouettes around the horizontal bar.
rings - Gymnasts perform feats of balance and strength from two suspended rings.
beam - Gymnasts perform leaps and flips from the much feared balance beam just 10 cm wide.
rhythmic - A mixture of dance and gymnastic moves.
clubs - Dance and gymnastic moves whilst juggling clubs.
hoop - A hoop is rolled and thrown whilst performing a dance routine.
ribbon - Gymnasts work through a pre-arranged routine whilst manipulating a spectacular length of ribbon.
rope - Jump and figure movements are performed while a rope is manipulated.
ball - An exercise based on suppleness of the body using a ball.
trampoline - Competitors perform complicated twists and turns whilst bouncing on the trampoline.
handball (team) - A ball game using the hands contested by two teams of seven trying to throw the ball into the opponents goal.
horse racing, harness racing - Mounted horse races.
flat racing - A horse race over a flat course.
steeple chase - A mounted horse race over at least eight classic obstacles, four of which must be different, such as the water jump, spruce fences, mud walls etc.
trotting - Horses pitched to a jockeyed buggy race in a trot round a flat course.
cross country - A long distance race including rustic obstacles such as real fences, streams and fallen trees.
ice hockey - Two teams of six heavily padded skaters try and outscore each other by hitting a puck into the opponents goal.
National Hockey League (North American) - Teams from the US and Canada make up the North American continents top league.
sledge hockey - Like ice hockey but instead of skates small sledges are used. Competitors move by pushing with the arms
Jai Alai (Pelota) - Because of the game organization, the proper identification of a specific game may require the combination of 2 subject details
fronton - The "fronton" known as "Fronton Place Libre" consists of a rectangular outdoor court plus a large pink shaped wall at one end. The two sides and the other end are left opened.
jai-alai - A "Jaï-Alai" is an indoor fronton with a 56 meters long court which is used exclusively to play "chistera-ancha". Three walls are used in the game

parents.item: the back and the left hand wall.

item.name: left wall - A "fronton with left hand wall" is an indoor fronton with a 36 meters long court where Pala or Main Nue are played. Three walls are used in the game

parents.item: the back and the left hand wall.

item.name: trinquet - A "Trinquet" is an indoor fronton with a 28.5 meters long court surrounded by four walls. The four walls are used in the game.
rebot - The "rebot" is the game played in a fronton "place libre" with 5 players in each team. They use a "chistera" (56 cm long and 12 cm large) or bare hands.

chistera ancha - The "chistera-ancha" also called the "cesta punta" is the game played in a "jaï alai" with 1 or 2 players in each team. The players use a long curved basket called the "chistera" (68 cm long and 13 cm wide).

chistera corta - The "chistera-corta" is the game played in a fronton "place libre" with left hand wall and 3 players in each team. The players use a long curved basket called the "chistera" (56 cm long and 12 cm wide).
bare hand - The "Main Nue" (bare hand) is the ancestor of all Basque sports.
pala-ancha - The "pala-ancha" is the game played in a fronton "place libre" with 2 players in each team. The players use a heavy wooden bat "the pala" (50 cm long and 20 cm wide).

pala-corta - The "pala-corta" is the game played in a fronton with left hand wall and 2 players in each team. The players use a heavy wooden bat the "pala-corta" (50 cm long and 10 cm wide). The "pala" is the name for a heavy wooden bat.
pasaka - The "pasaka" is the name of the game played in a trinquet by teams of 2 players facing each other on each side of a net where the pelota is hit between opponents.
xare - The "xare", is the name of the game played in a trinquet by teams of 2 players. The players use a "xare" (or the Argentina bat) 55 cm long and 16 cm wide.
judo - A defensive martial art.
heavyweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: open but usually over 100kg for men and over 78kg for women

item.name: half-heavyweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: up to 100kg for men and 78kg for women.

item.name: middleweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: up to 90kg for men and 70kg for women.

item.name: half-middleweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: up to 81kg for men and 63kg for women.

item.name: half-lightweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: up to 73kg for men and 57kg for women.

item.name: lightweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: up to 66kg for men and 52kg for women.

item.name: extra lightweight - Weight categoriy in Judo

parents.item: up to 60kg for men and 48kg for women.

item.name: karate - A martial art where chops, punches, kicks and throws are used to defeat an opponent.
sparring - Boxing without competition, with padded helmets
formal exercise-DEPRECATED - NA
lacrosse - Two teams of helmeted and padded players try and outscore each other using a netted stick and hard ball.

luge - Luge (French word for sled) is competed in singles or doubles. The competitor(s) lay on their back(s) on an open sled and race down a course. The competitor(s) and the sled must be in contact when passing the finishing line.
singles - individual time trial event in a one seater luge
doubles - time trial for a twin berth luge
marathon - A road race where competitors run 42.195km, generally through city streets
modern pentathlon - The Modern Pentathlon comprises five events run over a single day in the following order
running - Pentathlon event
shooting - Pentathlon event
swimming - Pentathlon event
fencing - Pentathlon event
showjumping - Pentathlon event
motor racing - Motor racing where speed and trusty mechanics are key
Formula One - Single cockpit car racing where 20 or so competitors race head to head over varied circuits around the world to win Grand Prix points in an individual and constructors championship
F3000 - Using less powerful motors than the Formula One, designated construction teams race over varied circuits the world over in speed races for individual and team honours over a season.
endurance - Endurance races for a driver and co-pilot using specially built cars.
Indy - North American top range professional league speed racing over circuits.
CART - North American professional league speed racing.
NHRA - North American professional league speed racing.
NASCAR - North American professional league speed racing.
TRUCKI - North American professional league speed racing.
motor rallying - A season of endurance races over closed circuits including dirt tracks, roads and even snowy conditions featuring specials using adapted road cars with a driver and co-pilot.
rallying - Stage races
pursuit - Cross-country race with mass start, first half of the distance in classic and the other half in free style.
rallycross - Stage races over dirt tracks
motorcycling - Races with 2, 3 or 4 wheels vehicles with a saddle and handlebars
speed-Grand-Prix - A fast and furious race where every second counts
enduro - A race of speed, endurance and regularity over varied surfaces such as through forests and on dirt tracks
grass-track - A race competed on turf
moto-ball - Team sport where drivers play a ball
moto-cross - Raced over dirt tracks featuring severe mounds
rallying - Races run over regular roads
trial - A race of consistency and endurance over varied terrain
endurance - A road race of consistency and endurance
superbike - Engine size
125 cm3 - Engine size
250 cm3 - Engine size
500 cm3 - Engine size
side-cars - Of different engine sizes but attached to a side car featuring a passenger
motoGP - Capacity class 1000ccm
netball - A woman's sport similar to basketball without a board behind the basket
nordic skiing - Practiced in snowy countryside and based on power and endurance. There are classic and free style events with mass or staggered starts.
cross-country - Nordic ski race
5 km classical time - A 5km classic race in that the competitor keeps his skis parallel except on steep inclines where the scissor move is used
10 km classical style - A 10km classic race in that the competitor keeps his skis parallel except on steep inclines where the scissor move is used
10 km pursuit free style - Staggered start depending on positions with competitors using a skating like technique on skis
15 km classical style - A 15km race using the classical style of keeping skies parallel
15 km pursuit free style - 15km race with staggered start using free style technique similar to a skating motion
10 km + 15 km combined - 10km classic followed by 15km free-style race
30 km classical style - A 30km classic race in that the competitor keeps his skis parallel except on steep inclines where the scissor move is used
30km free style - A 30km free-style race where the most common style is the skate style where competitors slide and the skis do not need to be parallel
50 km free style - A 50km free style race where the most common style is the skate style where competitors slide and the skis do not need to be parallel
4x5 km relay - Teams of four competitors ski 5km each in relay fashion
4x10 km relay - Teams of four competitors ski 10km each in relay fashion
nordic combined - A two day competition combining the ski jump and a cross-country race.
raid - NA
5 km pursuit free style - Cross-country skiing over a 5km course in a pursuit format
1.5 km sprint free - Cross-country skiing over a 1.5km course in a sprint format
50 km classic style - Cross-country skiing over a 50km course in a classic style format

orienteering - An individual time-trial over a route marked out by beacons. The competitor has to search out and find in a specific order. The contestant makes his way with the help of a compass and map

ski orienteering - An individual ski time-trial over a route marked out by beacons, that the competitor has to search out and find in a specific order. The contestant makes his way with the help of a compass and map

polo - With the aid of a mallet two teams of four horsemen try and knock a bamboo ball into the opponents goal over a pitch 250m long and 150m wide. The game is divided into 4, 6, or 8 time periods of 7min 30sec called chukkas.
power boating - Races between motor boats on rivers or lakes
F1 - Sprint race
F2 - Long distance race
rowing - Boat racing usually on flat calm waters with boats for 1, 2, 4 or 8 rowers
single sculls - Single person boats with two oars
double sculls - Two person boats with two oars each
quadruple sculls - Four person boats with two oars each and without a team mate to give directions
coxless pair - Two person boats with just one oar each and without a team mate to give directions
coxless four - Four person boats with just one oar each and without a team mate to give directions
eight - Eight person boats with just one oar each and without a team mate to give directions
lightweight - Where a weight category is imposed on competitors

rugby league - Two teams of 13 compete on a pitch where they score tries and penalties by running with and passing an oval ball to be touched down behind the goal line or kicked between goal posts in a tough physical contest

rugby union - Two teams of 15 compete on a pitch where they score tries and penalties by running with and passing an oval ball to be touched down behind the goal line or kicked between goal posts in a tough physical contest

rugby 7 - A more fun and exciting variety where two teams of 7 compete on a pitch where they score tries and penalties by running with and passing an oval ball to be touched down behind the goal line or kicked between goal posts in a tough physical contes
sailing - Sail boat racing over a route marked by buoys.

505 - Boat Category
staging race - Sea racing
around the world - Open seas racing
monohull - Single hull craft
multihulls - Multi hull craft

yngling - Olympic boat-class. A race around different courses in a boat of 6.35 metres (20ft 10in) long and 1.73 metres (5ft 8in) wide, crewed in Olympic competition only by women. The number of races and the length of the courses varies.

mistral - Olympic boat class. A staged race using boats of the mistral type, which are 4.24 metres (13ft 11in) long and 1.3 metres (4ft 3in) wide. The number of races and the length of the courses varies.
shooting - Precision sport using a hand gun, rifle or shotgun
10 m air rifle - Shooting event
10 m air pistol - Shooting event
10 m running target - Shooting event
25 m rapid fire pistol - Shooting event
25 m sport pistol - Shooting event
50 m free pistol - Shooting event
50 m free rifle prone - Shooting event
50 m free rifle 3x40 - Shooting event
50 m sport rifle 3x20 - Shooting event
trap - Shooting event with moving targets
double trap - Shooting event with two moving targets launched at the same time
skeet - Shooting event with moving targets, competitor shoots from a series of positions
ski jumping - Competitors descend a snow covered elevated ramp on skis and try to fly off it as far as possible, receiving marks for distance, style of flight and landing
K90 jump - Competitors jump from 70m and must clear 90m distance in their jump before scoring points for it
K120 jump - Competitors jump from 90m and must clear 120m distance in their jump before scoring points for it
K180 (flying jump) - Competitors jump from 180m and must clear 180m in their jump before scoring points for it
snow boarding - Practiced with a single board (rather than two skis)
giant slalom - Knock-out head-to-head downhill racing
half-pipe - Over a semi-cylindrical tube of 100m competitors must perform a series of moves that are marked for style by 5 judges
soccer - Two teams of eleven try to kick or head a ball into the opponents goal over a match usually of 90 minutes
softball - Similar to baseball but with a larger and softer ball, a thinner bat, shorter gaps between bases and less innings
speed skating - Timed races competed by two skaters at a time on an oval ice track
500 m - Speed skating race over 500m
1000 m - Speed skating race over 1000m
1500 m - Speed skating race over 1500m
3000 m - Speed skating race over 3000m
5000 m - Speed skating race over 5000m
10000 m - Speed skating race over 10000m
Short-track - Races of four or more skaters on an oval ice track. Qualifying, semi-finals and finals determine winners.
st 500 m - Short track speed skate race over 500m
st 1000m - Short track speed skate race over 1000m
st 1500m - Short track speed skate race over 1500m
st 3000m - Short track speed skate race over 3000m
st 3000m relay - Short track relay speed skate race over 3000m
st 5000m - Short track speed skate race over 5000m
st 5000m relay - Short track relay speed skate race over 5000m
speedway - Fast track
sports organisations - Organisations responsible for a specific sport
IOC - International Olympic Committee
international federation - A body responsible for the international coordination of a specific sport
continental federation - A body responsible for the continental coordination of a specific sport
national federation - A body responsible for the national coordination of a specific sport
GAISF - General Association of International Sports Federations
squash - A racket sport of strategy and endurance played by singles or doubles teams in a walled court with a small rubber ball
sumo wrestling - A combat sport of speed and rapidity with much ceremony where two contestants try to throw or slap a competitor out of a marked area. Generally practiced in Japan by large men.
surfing - Water sport where contestants catch and ride waves upright on a surfboard
swimming - A water sport where contestants swim as fast as possible in a given style and win races by being the first to touch home
50 m freestyle - Competitors cover 50m in any style, though front crawl is universally employed
100 m freestyle - Competitors cover 100m in any style, though front crawl is universally employed
200 m freestyle - Competitors cover 200m in any style, though front crawl is universally employed
400 m freestyle - Competitors cover 400m in any style, though front crawl is universally employed
800 m freestyle - Competitors cover 800m in any style, though front crawl is universally employed
1500 m freestyle - Competitors cover 1500m in any style, though front crawl is universally employed
relay 4x50 m freestyle - Teams of four swimmers cover 50m freestyle in a 200m race
relay 4x100 m freestyle - Teams of four swimmers cover 100m freestyle in a 400m race
relay 4x200 m freestyle - Teams of four swimmers cover 200m freestyle in a 800m race
50 m backstroke - Competitors cover 50m in the backstroke style
100 m backstroke - Competitors cover 100m in the backstroke style
200 m backstroke - Competitors cover 200m in the backstroke style
50 m breaststroke - A 50m race in the breaststroke style, on the front, effecting forward and outward push movements with the arms and backward and outward pushes with the legs
100 m breaststroke - A 100m race in the breaststroke style, on the front, effecting forward and outward push movements with the arms and backward and outward pushes with the legs
200 m breaststroke - A 200m race in the breaststroke style, on the front, effecting forward and outward push movements with the arms and backward and outward pushes with the legs

50 m butterfly - A 50m butterfly race, swum on the front with the shoulders remaining parallel to the water both arms moving in simultaneous windmill fashion, the legs remain together and are moved in a flapping motion. The most physical of all styles.

100 m butterfly - A 100m butterfly race, swum on the front with the shoulders remaining parallel to the water both arms moving in simultaneous windmill fashion, the legs remain together and are moved in a flapping motion. The most physical of all styles

200 m butterfly - A 200m butterfly race, swum on the front with the shoulders remaining parallel to the water both arms moving in simultaneous windmill fashion, the legs remain together and are moved in a flapping motion. The most physical of all styles
100 m medley - Swimmers complete four laps, each in a different style and in this order
200 m medley - Swimmers complete four laps, each in a different style and in this order
400 m medley - Swimmers complete eight laps, two in each style and in this order
relay 4x50 m medlay - A relay team of four, each of whom completes a single lap and each in a different style in this order

item.name: relay4x100 m medley - A relay team of four, each of whom completes two laps and each in a different style in this order

item.name: short course - Races competed in a 25m length pool

synchronised technical routine - Contestants obtain points from 10 sitting judges by executing certain synchronised artistic shapes and movements in the water. In the technical programme, competitors must execute a range of specific moves in a given order
synchronised free routine - In the free programme, music, movements and their order of execution are not restricted.
table tennis - A racket sport for two or four (in doubles), who compete at a table divided by a net using a small bat to play a lightweight ball
Taekwon-Do - A martial art of Korean origin
under 49 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
under 58 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
49-57 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
58-68 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
57-67 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
68-80 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
over 67 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do
over 80 kg - Weight category in Taekwon-Do

tennis - A sport where two players, four in doubles, equipped with a racket compete by hitting the ball over a net into the opponent's side of the court with the aim of putting it out of reach within the regulation lines, thus winning points.
soft tennis - Tennis with a soft rubber ball. (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)

triathlon - An endurance multi-sport where competitors first swim, then cycle and then run a road race. Distances vary according to the competition, the Olympic version being 1.5, 40 and 10km respectively.
triathlon swimming - Triathlon event
triathlon cycling - Triathlon event
triathlon run - Triathlon event

volleyball - Two teams of six record points by hitting a ball over a net into the opponent's half of the court, keeping it in the air at all times. Points are won when opponents fail to return the ball.

beach volleyball - Two teams of two players compete on a sand court. Unlike indoor volleyball, points are scored only when the serving team wins a rally or forces an error. The sand surface makes it more physically demanding than volleyball.
water polo - Played in a pool between two teams of 7, who must stay afloat and can only use one hand to pass the ball or swim with it before trying to throw it into the opponents net to score goals.
water skiing - On one or two skis contestants are pulled by a power boat along the water's surface
slalom - Speed event where contestants round a course marked out by buoys
trick - Skiers perform a maximum of figures in a limited time period
jump - Skiers perform as long a jump as possible from a ramp in the water
combined - A combined event made up of the slalom, jump and trick
weightlifting - A strength test where competitors lift as heavy a weight as possible
snatch - The bar must be lifted from floor to above the head in one movement
clean and jerk - The bar is first lifted to the shoulders and then jerk it above the head and keep it there while maintaining straight legs
48 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
53 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
63 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
75 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
over 75 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
56 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
62 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
69 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
77 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
85 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
94 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
105 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
over 105 kg - Competitor weight category in weightlifting
powerlifting - A strength test where competitors lift as heavy a weight as possible
windsurfing - Contestants must complete a marked out course as fast as possible on a windsurf board
ocean - Races on the open seas
lake - Races competed on lakes
river - Races competed on rivers
land - Races competed on land with a board equipped with wheels
wrestling - Combat sport where each wrestler attempts to win over his adversary, by holding both shoulders on the ground (fall) long enough to be in control. Points can also be decisive.
freestyle - A style where leg holds are allowed
greco-roman - A style where the only holds allowed are those between the head and the belt
over 130 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
130 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
97 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
85 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
76 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
69 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
63 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
58 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
54 kg - Competitor weight category in wrestling
Swiss wrestling - Traditional Swiss sport similar to wrestling with specific rules
sports event - Sports meeting
Summer Olympics - Summer Olympics
Winter Olympics - Winter Olympics
Summer universiade - Summer universiade
Winter Universiade - Winter Universiade
Commonwealth Games - Commonwealth Games
Winter Goodwill Games - Winter Goodwill Games
Summer Asian Games - Summer Asian Games
Winter Asian Games - Winter Asian Games
Panamerican Games - Panamerican Games
African Games - African Games
Mediterranean Games - Mediterranean Games
SouthEast Asiatic Games - SouthEast Asiatic Games
PanPacific Games - PanPacific Games
SouthPacific Games - SouthPacific Games
PanArabic Games - PanArabic Games
Summer Goodwill Games - Summer Goodwill Games
World games - A competition featuring world class athletes
World Cup - Sports meeting with competitors from the five continents
intercontinental cup - Sports meeting bringing together competitors from different continents
continental cup - Sports meeting where competitors come from a single continent
international cup - Sports meeting where competitors come from several nations
National Cup - Sports meeting where competitors come from a single nation
interregional cup - Sports meeting where competitors come from several regions
regional cup - Sports meeting where competitors come from a single region
league cup - A competition within a sports league
world championship - A championship where competitors from the five continents take part
intercontinental championship - A championship where competitors from the different continents take part
continental championship 1st level - A championship where top level competitors from a single continent take part
continental championship 2nd level - A championship where second string competitors from a single continent take part
continental championship 3rd level - A championship where third string competitors from a single continent take part
national championship 1st level - A championship where top level competitors from a single nation take part
national championship 2nd level - A championship where second string competitors from a single continent take part
national championship3rdlevel - A championship where third string competitors from a single continent take part
national championship 4th level - A championship where fourth string competitors from a single continent take part
regional championship - A championship where competitors from a single region take part
Grand Prix - High level sports competition, most often motor racing
intercontinental tournament - Tournament where competitors from several continents take part
continental tournament - Tournament where competitors from a single continent take part
international tournament - Tournament where competitors from several nations take part
national tournament - Tournament where competitors from a single nation take part
inter-nations competition - Tournament where athletes from several nations take part
inter-clubs competition - Tournament where competitors from several clubs take part
friendly competition - Sports played but not in a tournament
all-stars competition - Competition between teams made up of invited stars
exhibition - demonstration
Super Bowl - The American football final that determines the champion
paralympic games - Olympic style Games for athletes with a disability
rodeo - A discipline where wild horses or bulls must be mounted and mastered
barrel racing - Rodeo discipline
calf roping - Rodeo discipline
bull riding - Rodeo discipline
bulldogging - Rodeo discipline
saddle bronc - Rodeo discipline
bareback - Rodeo discipline
goat roping - Rodeo discipline
mini golf sport - A game where balls must be holed on an artificial course in as few strokes from the club as possible

bandy - Played outdoors on ice. The size of the ice rink is about the size of a soccer field. Skates like ice hockey. A small hard ball is used for playing. Players play with sticks, much like in ice hockey, but the sticks are shorter and more rounded.

flying disc - A group of events all played with a flying plastic disc. The exact regulation for the disc is different in different events but it has to be unbroken of solid plastic and a production model with no modification. Flying disc is sometimes call

ultimate - Team game. Played outdoors on soccer-size field with 7 players per team and indoors with 5 players per team. Games are played to a preset number of goals. Goals are scored by passing the disc to a team-member catching it inside the goal area.
guts - Team game where two teams of 5 players each face each other. Teams take turns to throw the disc towards the other team. Points are scored if the opposing team does not catch the disc.
overall - Not an event in itself but in most competitions with individual events the winner of the competition will be awarded to the player with the highest combined score in the events.
distance - The object is to throw the disc as far as possible. Each player get five throws per turn. Throws are made downwind. World record is over 200 meters.

discathon - The object is to throw and run a park course of about 1 kilometre. Four players compete in each heat. They have two discs each. They may also carry a third disc in reserve. Where one thrown disc stops the second disc must be thrown.

DDC - Abbreviation for Double Disc Court. Two players per team in a square 13x13 metre. The teams start with one disc per team and throw at each other. Discs are thrown back and forth until one or both hit the ground.

SCF - Abbreviation for Self Caught Flights. Divided into two sub events called MTA (Maximum Time Aloft) and TRC (Throw Run Catch). In both sub events the player throws a disc and then runs to catch it with one hand before it hits the ground.

freestyle - A judged event where groups of two or three players perform as many tricks as possible. In competitions the judges can use either a ranking system or set scores on presentation, execution and difficulty.
accuracy - Each player has 28 throws from various distances and angles to throw the disc through a goal 1.5 x 1.5 meters. World record is 25 of 28 possible.

disc golf - Much like golf but played with discs instead of balls and clubs. Instead of a hole in the ground there is a metal basket with light metal chains to throw the disc at. Players often carry discs specialized for long throws, right or left bends.

floorball - Played indoors in a court the size of a basketball court. 6 players per team, of which one is a who plays in a kneeling position without a stick like in ice hockey. The other players use plastic clubs and a light plastic ball to pass and shoot
casting - Using fishing equipment to hit a target and score points
tug-of-war - Two teams pulling against each other on a rope
croquette - Using mallets to hit a ball through hoops
dog racing - Dogs racing around a track
sled - Harnessed to a sled
oval track - Pursuing an artificial rabbit around an oval track

skeleton - In skeleton the competitor lays on his/hers stomach when racing down the course. The competitor must be on the sled when crossing the finishing line. The total time of all races in a competition is added together.
Australian rules football - Football played under Australian rules
Canadian football - Football played under Canadian rules
duathlon - Duathlon
hornuss - Swiss team sport with 16 or 18 men per team. A rubber puck is hit towards the field of the adversary team which tries to hit the puck in the air with a wooden board thrown in the air
fist ball - Men's team sport similar to volleyball (with a much lower net) executed mainly in gymnastics clubs
inline skating - Competitive sports using inline skates
grass ski - Alpine skiing on roller skis and grass
snowbiking - Individual sport on snow on a snow bike, the athlete has two mini skis, previous name
twirling - Team competition with majorettes and a jury
kendo - Japanese traditional martial art using a bamboo sword, sometimes called Japanese fencing. (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)
jukendo - Japanese traditional martial art using a model rifle made of wood. "Juken" means a rifle or gun with blade (bayonet). (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)
naginata - Japanese traditional martial art using a pole sword made of wood. "Naginata" means a spear with a curved blade. (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)
kyudo - Japanese traditional martial art using a bamboo bow and arrows, sometimes called Japanese archery. (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)
kabaddi - The attacking side scores by touching, and the side to guard scores by capturing. The attacker continues calling it "kabaddi".
sepak takraw - The game like volleyball which must not use a hand. The ball made of rattan is used. (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)
wushu - Generally, Chinese traditional martial art. (Programme of National Sports Festival in Japan)
darts - Two players compete by throwing metal darts at a wall-mounted circular board divided radially into segments of different scores
bodybuilding - A person displays pronounced muscle tone and exaggerated muscle mass and definition for overall aesthetic effect
sports disciplinary action - Actions, including fines and suspensions levied by sports organisations and teams
sports awards - Awards and honors given by sports organisations or won by sports figures
unrest, conflicts and war - Acts of socially or politically motivated protest and/or violence.
act of terror - Act of violence, often deadly, designed to raise fear and anxiety in a population
armed conflict - Disputes between opposing groups involving the use of weaponry, but not formally declared a war
civil unrest - Dissatisfaction among the general population as evidenced by rallies, strikes, demonstrations or sabotage
revolutions - An often violent change in a nation's system of government by internal forces that results in systematic social change.
rebellions - Armed uprising by citizens of a nation with the intent to overthrow the government, without necessarily achieving social change
political dissent - Disagreement between political groups, usually organized and sometimes resulting in imprisonment of the dissenters
religious conflict - Conflicts involving religious differences
social conflict - Conflicts involving social differences
coup d'etat - The overthrow of an established government by an organized group, often the military or a political party
guerrilla activity - Anti-government actions by clandestine groups using hit-and-run techniques or sabotage, kidnapping and the like
bioterrorism - Use of biological agent to raise the level of fear within a population, whether deaths occur or not.
bombings - Use of explosive devices against people, buildings or structures
massacre - The death of a large group of people over a brief period of time
genocide - Systematic killing of one clan, tribe or ethnic type by another
riots - Violent, destructive demonstrations often involving injury to individuals and destruction of property
demonstration - A public show of feeling or opinion, as by a mass meeting or parade
war - A formal declaration of hostilities by one country against another
civil war - Armed conflict between members of the same nation or geographical region, in some cases with a desire to divide the nation or region.
international military intervention - Temporary use of international forces by invitation or by a decision of an outside body in another country or region for the purpose of resolving a crisis.
prisoners and detainees - People captured and imprisoned by their enemy during war or armed conflict
conflict (general) - A dispute which can be at several levels,
peacekeeping force - Varied national military forces under unified international command to maintain order in disputed areas.
crisis - Conflict of all kinds that rises to a level where, depending on events, governments can fall, war be declared or stock markets crash, or not
weaponry - Armaments of all types used to conduct war
weather - The study, reporting and prediction of meteorological phenomena.
forecast - Prediction of the course of the weather in the future either near term or long term
global change - The determination whether the Earth is getting warm, or colder, whether seas are rising or falling and the like
report - Any distributed announcement about the weather
weather news - General information about weather events
statistic - Numerical facts about the weather such as temperature, barometric pressure, river levels, humidity, high and low tides and the like
warning - Alerts to the general populace about severe weather coming their way
DPI - Division of Public Information
ERI - Sector for External Relations and Public Information
Departments
Subject Code - The Subject Codes is IPTC 's original subject taxonomy, with a focus on text. It consists of about 1400 terms organized into 3 levels.
